This problem looks like another great use for Monte Carlo simulation (when you have a hammer, every problem starts to look like a nail... ). I ran a simulation based on the volatility (getting data for this simulation was a pain, does anyone know of a good data source?). The market is turbulent, but there isn't a lot of time left for this question, so it seems pretty likely that we'll remain in the "More than $2.5 trillion" bucket. The crowd looks pretty much aligned to my simulation results. There might be good reasons to think the market will do something different than the simulation results forecast, but it seems to be a reasonable "outside view". 
{
  "Less than $1.0 trillion":	0.01%,
  "Between $1.0 trillion and $1.5 trillion, inclusive":	0.25%,
  "More than $1.5 trillion but less than $2.0 trillion":	3.75%,
  "Between $2.0 trillion and $2.5 trillion, inclusive":	17.55%,
  "More than $2.5 trillion":	78.44%,
}
CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/tree/master/coin_cap
ENGINE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/monte_carlo_forecasting/MonteCarlo.py

Crypto rose this past week, so adjusting upward to account for that. Virtually all the near-term news is bullish:
- good macro environment with lots of excess cash to "find a home."  Top-down, COVID variants and vaccine "breakthrough" are renewing pressure on central banks to pump liquidity and keep raise low (inside this forecasting window. Taxes will rise but it's outside this forecasting window.
- Ethereum "London fork" successfully rolled out. This pressures Bitcoin to launch taproot without delay and pressures other innovation as well.
- Europe approved first crypto ETF. More pressure on SEC to approve.
- US regulation is medium/long term positive: remember, by default capital is scared of crypto and stays on the sidelines, so any reasonable regulation = acceptance = $ = marketcap. It was looking dicey this weekend, but the various competing bills appear to be resolving in favor of "reasonable" legislation: crypto is a golden goose for tax revenue, and nobody wants to kill that.
- more companies and funds are buying crypto - and we're not seeing *any* companies reduce their holdings or exit.
- capital continues to "come over" from gold ($10T). "bitcoin = digital gold" meme continues to gain steam e.g. regularly mentioned by strategy people at Fidelity, Goldman, etc. In the next phase, we'll start to hear crypto mentioned when the discussion topic is gold. For example, https://www.google.com/search?q=gold+investment is starting to show news articles about Bitcoin. The next phase after that, gold starts dropping (substantially) and "gold bugs" start capitulating - that's outside this forecasting window.
- altcoins continue to strengthen: DeFi continues to gain respect and silicon valley insiders are bullish on legitimate uses for NFTs, driving $$$ investment. Altcoins are smaller marketcap, but drive excitement. The scams and meme-coins are losing attention, which makes "room" in the media for legit tokens that have provide infrastructure and utility to real applications. Reasons not to go 100% on >$2.5T:
1. black swan events and bad news on the particular week the forecast closes.
2. $2.5T = BTC@$63K (assuming same ratios as today)... that's on the edge of trader "resistance level" which might not happen precisely on Dec 9. Volatility remains high, so I expect to adjust next week.

growing more bullish:  - causes for concern are going away: every month that Tether fails to unwind is another month for USDC/etc to grow up and replace it, and also Tether earns trading fees to help backfill any "missing" money. Also, if Tether crashes, it's unclear what effect this has: Tether holders would rush to the exit to buy Bitcoin but then $xB evaporates from the market and it becomes harder to transact Bitcoin. - Dec is still a long way away (for crypto), also the reason for 28% neutral/bearish - anything can happen, including a market crash that destroys capital. - DeFi: I've researched the "source" of DeFi's crazy interest rates, and I'm satisfied that they're legit/sustainable and not a Ponzi-type scheme (anymore than "money" is fake right now...). If mainstream savers realize this, it will drive tons of capital into crypto. NOTE: some of these interest rates are part of "proof of stake" and money-printing inherent to the cryptos themselves ("mining"), i.e. on a long term basis, staking interest just counterbalances mining dilution. BUT that's measured in years, and we're talking weeks and months where those same cryptos are trending higher anyway. - CBDCs are not a near term threat - totally theoretical, and even once they decide to launch, it takes years to establish governance, write and test code, and create on/off ramps from legacy financial systems. Plus, one mistake and adoption will be tepid (and they're statistically-likely to make several, since this is new to them and they're under political pressures to do stupid things: remember, these aren't experienced silicon valley folks) - inflation: Delta and other COVID variants are going to hammer the "real" economy again (esp developing countries whose economies can't grow using innovation) - this will drive more need for government intervention and money printing, causing savers to flee to inflation protected assets like crypto. nice summary, but again, watch out for timing:

I think we can see from how cryptocurrencies acted today that they do not act non correlated to the stock market. After the high inflation numbers today both the stock market and Bitcoin crashed. Of course, gold crashed as well but gold always crashes at first and then only starts climbing after sustained trouble with the stock market. As inflation continues to be high it will bring down the markets and crypto with it.
Crypto's pattern is to exude volatility. I would not be surprised if it declines much further and then rockets because of geopolitical events.

Given no income stream the dollar market cap of crypto is precisely the number of dollars invested. More dollars invested equals more market cap. That's why it's often called a "store of value." The crypto market is highly correlated with the broader equities market and global investor sentiment. Given COVID recovery unknowns and complex politics, assume volatility. Crypto is enjoying secular growth: previous metals investors allocating 100+B to crypto, the potential for near term US ETF approval (enabling millions of consumers to allocate 100s billions in retirement accounts), ongoing new offerings from large instructions including Goldman Sachs, etc. Venture capital is pouring into DeFi which in turn is drawing capital eager to access new products, especially lending. NFTs were goofy in "version 1" but in fact are a real revolution in digitizing ownership, especially digital rights - again drawing awareness and capital. I believe there will be a big COVID resurgence in the fall (easy prediction given variants, low vaccination rates and some amount of vaccine-escape) which will impact world economies but then quickly force western governments to inject capital (a.k.a. print money) and scare fiat holders to increase allocation into inflation protected asset classes. Interestingly, big dollar holders are struggling to store their dollars (banks refusing large deposits, negative interest rates etc) and crypto may seem attractive to companies like Apple. Crypto has ongoing risks: at any moment (or never) there could be a "run in the bank" with tether prior to USDC/etc replacing it. Very large "whale" investors could manipulate the market (as it appears they did in this spring's crash).  Regulation appears to be neutral: on one hand, it can create short term headwinds. OTOH, regulation makes crypto appear safer to investors and their draws more capital. Crypto is still dominated by Bitcoin and Bitcoin price influenced heavily by halving events. That periodicity isn't telling in this case: on one hand, we could be at the top from the most recent halving, on the other hand, history suggests that topping should exceed $125,000. Finally, it's worth looking at buyers and sellers. As above, there appears to be large and growing pool of buyers ready to buy. Anecdotally, traders seen to be excited by the low $20,000s which implies a floor above that. If we look at the crypto sellers, two thirds of crypto is held by long term HODLers under no pressure to sell. https://insights.glassnode.com/bitcoin-supply-distribution/ - my sense is that this a neutral effect: it won't stop a crash from happening but also doesn't create heightened risks of one happening (by comparison to an asset held mostly by retail investors). Even you sum it up, my sense:
- crypto remains correlated to Bitcoin which remains correlated to the stock market.
- if I had to pick a floor, I'd say $22000 (0.93T market cap) but of course it could crash further especially in a global financial crisis e.g. war (e.g. Russian cyber attacks on the US escalate to cyber war, causing widespread disruptions)
- realistically, the Dec ceiling would be $100,000-200,000 both safely above $2.5T (I'm ~55% invested in selected real estate, ~8% cash and ~25% in crypto, roughly spread by market cap, overweighting selected "utility" altcoins and ignoring a few, including meme cryptos & pump/dump nonsense)

I'm using Bitcoin as a proxy and ballpark the market caps to Bitcoin price at roughly $20,000, $32,000, $44,000, & $56,000.  if we do historical prices, it captures a lot of the variability, but I don't think the probabilities are so good. A Monte Carlo walk, on the other hand, looks about right. CBBTCUSD probability table run on 2021-07-10 for 2021-12-09 forecast:
====================================================
Prob. | Bins 
====================================================
0.054 | Bin 1 - <20000
0.115 | Bin 2 - 20000 to <=32000
0.214 | Bin 3 - 32000+ to <44000
0.261 | Bin 4 - 44000 to <=56000
0.356 | Bin 5 - 56000+
====================================================
Number of Monte Carlo simulations: 10000 CBBTCUSD probability table run on 2021-07-10 for 2021-12-09 forecast:
====================================================

====================================================

0.233 | Bin 2 - 20000 to <=32000

China War against Bitcoin Will be over

Cryptocurrencies are technically making a clear head and shoulders formation, which suggests a drop to come. Really crypto doesn't have much for fundamentals to look at so all you can look at is the technical pattern.  Crypto really isn't a non-correlated asset to the stock market like a lot of people claim. It behaves a lot more like a growth stock of a tech company that has never made a profit like uber or Netflix or doordash or we work. When the stock market crashes crypto tends to drop as well. So as stagflation hits the economy over the next 6 months I expect crypto to suffer. It's also important to realize that much of the cryptocurrency value has been leveraged. Many people have taken out loans against their Bitcoin value, so if Bitcoin drops at a certain point this will cause increased selling because people will effectively have margin calls and will need to cover their loans.  Also, crypto does not have market stops like the stock exchange does. The stock exchanges will halt trading if the market drops a certain amount and allow panic to cool off. Crypto could theoretically drop to zero in an hour.
